questions.explanation: Natural numbers start from 1, so 0 is not considered a natural number.
Addition is commutative because a + b = b + a.
Subtraction is not associative; (a - b) - c ≠ a - (b - c).

question.text: Multiplying any number by zero gives zero.

questions.explanation: By the multiplication property of zero, any number × 0 = 0.

question.text: Division by zero is defined in mathematics.

questions.explanation: Division by zero is undefined and leads to a mathematical error.

question.text: Every whole number is also a natural number.

questions.explanation: Whole numbers include 0, which is not a natural number.

question.text: The result of adding two odd numbers is always even.
The product of two negative numbers is positive.
An even number divided by 2 always gives an odd number.

questions.explanation: Even ÷ 2 may give either even or odd. For example, 4 ÷ 2 = 2 (even).

question.text: Multiplication is both commutative and associative.

questions.explanation: Multiplication satisfies both the commutative and associative properties.
